Additional info:
I've been modeling in Blender since about 2015 but more recently in the past couple of years. I've been making games and assets in Unity since 2011 and I'm currently working on a multiplayer RTS game that I'll be happy to announce later this year.

I use a Panasonic Lumix GH5 camera to record my videos with the Olympus 17mm F1.2 lens as well as the Laowa F2.0 7.5mm compact dreamer lens. Sometimes I also use a GoPro Hero 8, a Insta360 One X and a Sony rx100 mark vii. For audio I use a Rode NTG shotgun microphone connected to a RME Fireface UFX II sound card.

Thanks a lot for watching and sharing my videos :)

snippet.title: Changing Action Maps with Unity's "New" Input System
snippet.description:
Changing actions maps with Unity's new input system is easy and allows precise control of which inputs are being listened to - switching between a 3rd person controller, vehicle controller or UI buttons. An input manager can provide a static instance of an input action asset as well as centralized control of toggling action maps making implementation easy and error-free.

Version 1.0.2 of the input system was used along with Unity 2020.3

snippet.title: Activate ray tracing with Unity's High Definition Render Pipeline | NVIDIA webinar
snippet.description:
In this webinar, you’ll learn how to use Unity’s High Definition Render Pipeline (HDRP) wizard to enable ray-tracing in your Unity project—with just a couple of clicks. We’ll showcase in detail the following ray-traced effects: ambient occlusion, reflection, global illumination, shadows, recursive rendering, and path tracing. We’ll also explain how to use the various debug views to isolate these effects and offer recommendations to ensure a suitable frame rate for a wide variety of use cases, from games to high-end visualizations. Unity 2020 LTS is recommended for the latest ray-tracing features.

snippet.title: Implementing Scene Switching - An Elevator Between Scenes - Part 2
snippet.description:
Continuing our elevator and asynchronous scene management system development let's try to build a 3-scene system that will allow us to create a base scene with the global game objects (our player, scene transition elevator, camera etc) and the two "floors" we'll be transitioning between.

Our goal is to unload the currently loaded floor (if one is loaded) and replace it with the new scene before opening the elevator to reveal the changed scene. If we were to reverse this order or tried to unload and load the scenes simultaneously, we could end up in a situation where both of our playable scenes were loaded at the same time. For a completely static scene this is probably fine, but any dynamic objects like physics, ai etc could potentially attempt to interact with the other scene and cause behavior we don't want.

The flow we're trying to create with this effect should look something like this.

```mermaid
graph LR
    B(Try to load First Floor)
    C(Close Elevator Door)
    D{Is A Floor Loaded Already?}
    E(Unload Loaded Floor)
    F(Load First Floor)
    G(Open Elevator Door)
    B--˃C
    C--˃D
    D-- Yes --˃E
    D-- No --˃F
    E--˃F
    F--˃G
```

***

The [**Elevator Between Scenes** series playlist](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLEwYhelKHmigCVDWNM5--f7PofdkvXbuZ)

snippet.title: [Blender 2.8/2.9] Game-ready Rigs #3 - Rigify for Game Engines (UE4/Unity/Godot)
snippet.description:
This is a new video in my Blender to Game Engines series (aka "Bridging the Gap"). Here is the full playlist:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLdcL5aF8ZcJvCyqWeCBYVGKbQgrQngen3

This video is made possible by the people who support me on Patreon and Gumroad. 
Get early access to CGDive content:
🔸Youtube Memberships
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCRSx...
🔹Patreon
https://www.patreon.com/cgdive
🔹Original courses and products by CGDive
https://gumroad.com/l/blender_games

Rigify rigs are not well-suited for games. If you export a vanilla Rigify rig to a game engine it will bring along many unnecessary bones and a bad hierarchy. 
 
In this video, I show a workflow to make any Rigify rig ready for games. The process is very similar to my previous video ("How to make existing rigs game-ready") but I also show some Rigify specific techniques and pitfalls.
As always the workflow complies with the "game-ready principle" that I  explained in the previous chapters.

RECOMMENDED PRODUCTS
❖Rig Anything With Rigify (coupon code "cgdive" = 20% off)
https://toshicg.gumroad.com/l/rigify
Alive! Animation course in Blender
https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/DmdxO
❖The art of effective rigging in Blender (coupon code "cgdive" = 10% off)) 
https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/AeQfrF
❖Hard Surface Rigging In Blender
https://blendermarket.com/products/hard-surface-rigging-in-blender?ref=356

https://gumroad.com/a/348001395/XzWpB

📝 Here's my Factory Automation game I've been working on for a while now.
It has all the features you would expect, you can place down Buildings, Mine Resources, place Conveyor Belts and convert those base resources into more complex items.
A while ago I was playing Dyson Sphere Program which is what made me want to make my own game in this genre, similar to Factorio or Satisfactory.
In total it was around 20 hours to build this which is actually quite a short amount of time given all the complex systems involved.
The core of the system is based on my Grid Building System that I covered in another video, that's why I was able to make this in such a short amount of time.

If you want to make sure you don't miss the next livestream hit the 🔔 bell icon!

snippet.title: [Blender 2.8/2.9] Game-ready Rigs #1 - (UE4/Unity/Godot)
snippet.description:
This is a new video in my Blender to Game Engines series (aka "Bridging the Gap"). Here is the full playlist:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLdcL5aF8ZcJvCyqWeCBYVGKbQgrQngen3

This video is made possible by the people who support me on Patreon and Gumroad. 
Get early access to CGDive content:
🔸Youtube Memberships
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCRSx...
🔹Patreon
https://www.patreon.com/cgdive
🔹Original courses and products by CGDive
https://gumroad.com/l/blender_games

Intro to Blender Armatures video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ERAScO1s8Zk

In this video, I try to explain the "fundamental principle" that will make your rigs ready for export to a game engine. What we do here will apply to almost any engine. In later chapters, I'll also make videos that are focused on a specific engine (Unreal/Unity/Godot). For each game, we cover we'll do slight modifications to this technique to get the best results out of it. But understanding this general workflow will make our work much easier so please don't skip this chapter!

The "basic principle" consists of splitting your character rig into a "game rig" and "control rig". The "control rig" allows you to easily animate your character in Blender. The "game rig" on the other hand is kept very simple, just the way game engines like it. We then establish a connection between the two rigs using constraints but avoiding any parent-child relationship between the two armature layers. 

This video demonstrates this technique when building a rig from scratch 

RECOMMENDED PRODUCTS
❖Rig Anything With Rigify (coupon code "cgdive" = 20% off)
https://toshicg.gumroad.com/l/rigify
Alive! Animation course in Blender
https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/DmdxO
❖The art of effective rigging in Blender (coupon code "cgdive" = 10% off)) 
https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/AeQfrF
❖Hard Surface Rigging In Blender
https://blendermarket.com/products/hard-surface-rigging-in-blender?ref=356
❖RBF Drivers
https://gumroad.com/a/348001395/XzWpB 
❖Bonera
https://gumroad.com/a/99062899/oXuxm


Chapters

snippet.title: Game Design BREAKDOWN Dyson Sphere Program
snippet.description:
🎮 Here's 13 Game Design Lessons from Dyson Sphere Program!
🌍 Get my Complete Courses! ✅ https://unitycodemonkey.com/courses
👇
👍 Learn to make awesome games step-by-step from start to finish.
🎮 Get my Steam Games https://unitycodemonkey.com/gamebundle
🤖 Follow the Steam Curator https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39734618-Game-Dev-Reviews-Code-Monkey/

🎮  In my Game Dev Review series I go through various games and give you my tips on Game Design and Game Mechanics from my point of view as a Professional Indie Game Developer.
Here we have Dyson Sphere Program, it's a Factory Automation Management game, in the same vein as Factorio or Satisfactory, you control a Mech and go through the whole Universe gathering resources, crafting items and automating your Production Lines.
Personally this is just my type of game so I loved it, if you enjoy creating supply lines and complex item crafting then you'll love this one.
Also it is made in Unity! This is an excellent showcase of what the engine can do.
Thousands of items all moving around and the game has excellent performance, makes me wonder if they're using DOTS or just the Job System or perhaps a custom ECS solution.

snippet.title: Outlines on One Object in Unity URP Shader Graph with Edge Detection! ✔️ 2020.3 | Game Dev Tutorial
snippet.description:
✔️ Works in 2020.1 ➕ 2020.2 ➕ 2020.3 🩹 Fixes:
► At line 39 in OutlinesInclude.hlsl, the sixth entry in sobelSamplePoints should be float2(1, 0), not float2(1, 1)

Outlines are a great way to add polish and style to a variety of games! In this tutorial, I apply depth and normal outlines to single objects, allowing different outline colors. This technique also skips the post processing step, which can be a big performance boost for lightweight platforms!

snippet.title: Blender(2.8/2.9):THE FUNDAMENTALS of Exporting Rigged characters to Unreal, Unity, or ANY GameEngine
snippet.description:
⚠️This video was the first one in what became a series about Blender & Game Engines. Some recommendations I made in this video have changed and they may keep changing. Check out the full playlist to stay up to date!
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLdcL5aF8ZcJvCyqWeCBYVGKbQgrQngen3 

LINKS
● Free scene files
⇒ https://gum.co/cgdive_free
● "The Art of Effective Rigging" - rigging course by Pierrick 
(enter "cgdive" at check-out to get 10% off)
⇒ https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/AeQfrF
● Arigify addon - one-click solution to prepare Rigify rigs for  Game Engines
(enter "cgdive" at check-out to get 5% off)
⇒ https://gumroad.com/a/361100403

●Support CGDive on Patreon 
https://www.patreon.com/cgdive
●CGDive Discord Group
⇒ https://discord.gg/YFH5HUv


RECOMMENDED PRODUCTS
❖Rig Anything With Rigify (coupon code "cgdive" = 20% off)
https://toshicg.gumroad.com/l/rigify
Alive! Animation course in Blender
https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/DmdxO
❖The art of effective rigging in Blender (coupon code "cgdive" = 10% off)) 
https://gumroad.com/a/183891059/AeQfrF
❖Hard Surface Rigging In Blender
https://blendermarket.com/products/hard-surface-rigging-in-blender?ref=356
❖RBF Drivers
https://gumroad.com/a/348001395/XzWpB 
❖Bonera
https://gumroad.com/a/99062899/oXuxm

If you struggle to export rigged and animated characters from Blender to any game engine (Unreal, Unity, Godot, etc.) chances are that you're missing some fundamental knowledge. This is the video I wish I had when I tried to figure out how to import animated skeletal meshes from b3d into a game engine. 

To get reliable results you need to understand the basic difference between a 3d creation suite like blender and a 3d game engine like UE4, Cry Engine, source. Once you figure out what is being exported and how the process is fairly simple. 

This is just the first in a series of videos but I consider it the most important one. 
In future videos, I'll try to cover specific export settings, tools that make your life easier, etc. But all of that won't be as useful if you don't understand the fundamentals.

RELATED VIDEOS from CGDive
● Crash Course in Blender Armatures
⇒ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ERAScO1s8Zk
● Rigify basic course
⇒ https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLdcL5aF8ZcJv68SSdwxip33M7snakl6Dx
● Weight Painting videos
⇒ https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLdcL5aF8ZcJsFEdlMJ7To0Iu9s-XCFV3W

Chapters
0:00 Intro & recommended videos
2:03 The Fundamental Problem
4:01 Basic Problem #1 Fancy Controls
7:33 Basic Problem #2 Shape Keys 
8:50 Basic Problem #3 Rigged meshes need Vertex Weights
12:59 Basic Problem #4 Modifiers 
15:30 Basic Problem #5 Bendy Bones
18:42 Basic Problems  - A Summary
19:46 Advanced Problem #1 Bone Hierarchy
23:26 Solution #1 "TGT-bones" (for new rigs)
27:30 Solution #2 "TGT-bones" (for existing rigs)
39:32 Advanced Problem #2 Squash and Stretch
39:46 Solution #1 - Avoid squash and stretch
41:01 Understanding the squash and stretch issue
43:36 Solution #2 Disconnect all stretchy bones 
45:39 The "All-around" Solution   
46:03 Arigify (addon)
51:36 FBX export - generalized settings
53:04 Export results (UE4 / Unreal Engine)
57:34 Results recap (Unreal)
59:11 Export results (Unity)
1:00:50 What's next (also please Like and Share :) )

snippet.title: How to MAKE a GAME - Learn Unity Beginners 2020 | Tutorial Part #1
snippet.description:
How to Make a Video Game in Unity for Beginners - Getting Started | Part 1 
#unity #gamedev #learncode
⚡  Subscribe to my channel: ⚡ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7NJLsf6IonOy8QI8gt5BeA?sub_confirmation=1

Learning how to make a game in Unity is not that hard. I am pretty sure that you have heard about this amazing game engine before and you have probably tried it at one point or another. If you are someone who likes to create online games or virtual environments, then this engine could be perfect for you. Since this engine is pretty new, most people still don't know how to use it properly, but that does not matter because after reading this article you will understand everything there is to know about this amazing engine.

It has never been easier to become a top-notch game developer. Thanks to this great game development tool, anyone can actually make a decent amount of money online doing what they love. All you need to do is know how to make a game in Unity for beginners. There is no better place to start learning than from the beginning because this tutorial will introduce you to all of the important information about this wonderful gaming platform. As a beginner, I would highly recommend that you follow the instructions included in this tutorial very carefully. There is a lot of cool stuff that you will get when you complete this tutorial and it will definitely make a big difference for your game development career. I personally I learned game dev thanks to brackets about 3 years ago.


I think that it would be perfect if you could find a Unity tutorial that was created by someone who has had tons of experiences as a professional game developer. Unfortunately, all the best programs are still in the process of being polished, so I guess that it is impossible for you to find someone who could teach you everything that you need to know about this amazing game engine. However, there is an easy way to get some good information on this subject and that is by looking for people that already know how to make a game in Unity for beginners tutorials. You can search on forums for game development forums where developers from all over the world will be looking for tips and tricks on their favourite development tool. If you really want to know how to make a game in Unity for beginners, this is the easiest and fastest way to learn it right from the comfort of your own home!


Everything you need to succeed
Unity is so much more than the world’s best real-time development platform – it’s also a robust ecosystem designed to enable your success. Join our dynamic community of creators so you can tap into what you need to achieve your vision.
https://unity.com/

snippet.title: The Journey: Ep. 5 | Open Projects
snippet.description:
The journey continues! Join our EMEA Creator Advocacy team once again for the last episode of the year, where we take a look together at the game architecture behind "Chop Chop", the first community-driven Unity Open Project.

All game systems are starting to come together, and in this episode we'll have a look at how they interact, paving the way for us to be able to create quests, dialogues, and progression. Plus, a "surprise" topic that was requested by the community.

snippet.title: Halloween Special - Carved Pumpkins by Imphenzia Discord Members

snippet.title: Unity Bolt vs C# Scrips - complete tutorial - which one is for you?
snippet.description:
Learn how to do platformer mechanics in Unity with Bolt Visual Scripting. I go through everything in detail and I also compare it to C# scripts for the exact same functionality. Get an introduction and learn bolt, or use the video to decide if visual scripting or C# scripting suits you better.

Time Stamps:
00:00 Intro
** BOLT SECTION
01:00 Install Bolt
02:33 Hero Controller - Create your first Visual Script / Flow Graph
03:20 Keyboard / Joystick Input
03:30 Player Movement Left/Right
08:00 Separating Movement to its own graph from the Hero Controller
08:20 Creating a "Super Unit" - reusable visual scripts
10:30 Creating a "Jump" Super Unit to make the player jump
15:00 Creating a "IsGrounded" Super Unit to avoid flappy bird air jumping
20:50 Creating a "Face Forward" Super Unit to turn the player left/right
23:45 Enable a running animation with Animator Controller
24:00 Transition between Idle and Run animation states
28:00 Reducing sliding effect of player
28:50 Creating a "Jump Animation" Super Unit for jump up animations
31:30 Creating a Animator Blend Tree between jump up/down poses
36:33 Adding a sound effect to jumping
38:20 Overview of all Visual Graphs to control the player
39:30 Creating a "Limit Fall Speed" Super Unit to prevent falling between tiles
42:30 Creating a smooth Camera Follow Visual Graph
** C# SECTION
49:30 Re-creating the Hero Controller in C#
50:00 Recreating the Move Graph in C#
52:02 Recreating the Jump Graph in C#
53:56 Recreating the Is Grounded Graph in C#
56:28 Recreating the Face Forward Graph in C#
57:36 Recreating the Move Animation Graph in C#
58:14 Recreating the Jump Fall Animation Graph in C#
59:46 Recreating the Limit Fall Speed Graph in C#
01:00:45 Recreating the Camera Fallow Graph in C#
01:02:30 Playing the jump sound effect in C#
01:04:00 Outro and Final Thoughts

snippet.title: Coding Adventure: Atmosphere
snippet.description:
The planets in my solar system project are looking a bit hostile and uninviting, so in this video I'll be attempting to add some cozy atmospheres around them.

Watch the previous solar system video: here: https://youtu.be/lctXaT9pxA0

Some notes:
• I made a little build where you can play with the atmosphere settings yourself, which you can find over here if you're interested: https://sebastian.itch.io/atmosphere-experiment

• A number of knowledgeable people have pointed out in the comments that reality is not nearly as simple as my little diagram around the 4 and a half minute mark, and that light does not literally wiggle up and down like a wave, so please note that the diagram is incorrect!

• This project was inspired by the game Outer Wilds, which I highly recommend playing!

Project Files:
The project is available over here: https://github.com/SebLague/Solar-System
If you'd like to get early access to future project files (and support the channel!) you can find my Patreon page here: https://www.patreon.com/SebastianLague

Resources:
https://developer.nvidia.com/gpugems/gpugems2/part-ii-shading-lighting-and-shadows/chapter-16-accurate-atmospheric-scattering
http://nishitalab.org/user/nis/cdrom/sig93_nis.pdf
https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/28895/why-is-the-sky-not-purple
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scattering

Music:
"Brief Respite" by Antti Luode
"When Rain Comes" by Tide Electric
"Door to Door Disco" by Bright Seed
"Reflections of Space and Time" by AEROPLANES
"In the Atmosphere" by Bad Snacks
"Reflections" by MK2
"Nidra in the Sky with Ayla" by Jesse Gallagher
"Far Away" by Antti Luode
"Frontier" by Shimmer

Sections:
00:00 Intro
00:32 Setup
02:46 Resources
03:25 Light Scattering
06:15 Coding the Shader
11:55 Initial Results
13:10 Adding Colour
15:20 Colourful Results
16:40 Optimisation
17:39 Stars
18:50 Exploration

snippet.title: LEARN UNITY - The Most BASIC TUTORIAL I'll Ever Make
snippet.description:
EXPAND for Time Stamp Links -- This is the most basic Unity tutorial I will ever make. If you are brand new to Unity, or if you want to make sure you’ve covered the basics, and if you want to learn how to write your first C# script - this is the video for you!

Over the course of 2 hours, I go through the User Interface, Game Objects, Transforms, Components, Prefabs, and writing your first C# script to get user input, how to fix your first bugs, and even how to refactor your code to improve it.

You can support me on Patreon:
https://patreon.com/imphenzia

New Imphenzia Merch is available:
https://teespring.com/stores/imphenzia

1:59:38 Making a platform game by asking yourself "Can I"?
2:03:04 My 4 Key Advices to making games in Unity

snippet.title: Making a Water Shader in Unity with URP! (Tutorial)
snippet.description:

The water shader can be simple or complex, and include the features you desire. Let your imagination get wild in this tutorial, or simply follow step-by-step to get about the same results!

https://on.unity.com/2BOctDN

snippet.title: Making of Low Poly Racing - ep 5 - Checkpoints and Lap Times - Unity
snippet.description:
Hello guys, welcome to Episode 5 of "The Making of Low Poly Racing". Some times you have to code "boring" stuff to make *fun game*. Maybe this is one of those parts. In episode 5 we're creating checkpoints for cars to drive through, keeping track of those checkpoints to do a half decent attempt and preventing cheating, and we'll keep track of lap count and lap times! 

After this episode we've got something that starts to resemble a game. Earlier we could drive, but now we can also compete!

In fact, whoever posts the fastest lap on YouTube with the hashtag #lowpolyracing before 1st of June 2020 00:00 (midnight) will win a $50 Steam Voucher! But you have to record your lap with something like OBS screen capture and post it on YouTube to prove your lap-time. You can play the game here, either in the WebGL version - or preferably the Windows download version as it has better performance and better looping engine audio: 
https://imphenzia.itch.io/low-poly-racing

Check out the video where I model the 10 Cars in 10 Minutes:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YALV3HqfdLY

snippet.description:

Let's learn how to make Animated Cursors/Mouse in Unity
This is an excellent way to add some extra polish to your game!

🌍 Code Monkey on Steam!
👍 Interactive Tutorials, Complete Games and More!
✅ Add to your Wishlist! 👉 https://store.steampowered.com/app/1294220/

I've used Animated Cursors extensively in my Survivor Squad Games
📦 Grab the Game Bundle at https://unitycodemonkey.com/gameBundle.php

We're going to start off with some basic RTS controls for controlling our character.
Then using Cursor.SetCursor(); we're going to modify the OS Cursor to a custom texture.
After that we apply some logic to constantly change the Texture in order to animate the Cursor.
And finally we expand upon it adding an Enum for various CursorTypes and swap between them in real-time.

Video Description:

In this video we go over the essentials of C# scripting for Unity Game development in just 15 Minutes.

Welcome to Unity3D C# scripting tutorial series. In this series you will learn how program in C# in unity to create awesome games. Writing scripts is one of the most important process of creating games in unity3d game engine. If you learn C# from ground up , you can create amazing games in unity. C# coding gives you a lot of control over unity, which you can use to do whatever you want in your game. If you are starting with unity game development scripting, you should start learning C# instead of javascript. C# allows you to write scripts for unity in a more organised way, which would help you to understand your game code later. If you want to be a game programmer then Unity and C# is a great way to start learning about various game development principles. Unity is a full fledged game engine, you can do anything you want, and when you have the power of C# in it, you can achieve anything easily. You can write more robust, readable, faster executable code for unity game development. You may have seen that Unity official tutorials also use C#, since it's better to write code in C# than javascript. javascript is a more free-form language, it gives you more freedom which is not that good in long run. If you want to write better code for unity game development, then you should write your code in unity with C#. C# is a great language developed by Microsoft for it's .net platform, and unity uses it as a scripting language.

Thanks a lot for watching this video, if you have any questions, write those in comments. I hope you enjoyed. Please subscribe and like , comment , share. Thank you very much. :)

snippet.title: Low Poly Racing - Making Of - Episode 4 - Unity and Blender
snippet.description:
Hello guys - here is the 4th episode of the making of Low Poly Racing! 

In this video, I start be refactoring some of the code to make it more reusable when adding more cars (for example AI cars or multiplayer controlled cars) and we switch to use a Game Manager and an Input Controller. This will rework some parts from the previous video, but that's common - as you figure out stuff during development, you refactor and change the code to improve it over and over again. We also break out so that the Wheel component is separate, now you could add as many wheels as you'd like to a car or a truck without having to write any additional code.

We also implement some better cartoony gravity and wheel colider settings to get the car to jump, accelerate, and turn better to keep an arcade style feel. 

Then, we finish off by putting trees, stones, tire barriers, and fences with colliders and rigidbody physics. The fences get a Fixed Joint component so they stick to the environment for lighter impacts (guiding the cars back onto the roads) but if they get a direct hit they'll break off in sections.

This is quite a lengthy video - I hope it can give you some more understanding when making a game similar to this.

Check out the video where I model the 10 Cars in 10 Minutes:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YALV3HqfdLY

Check out Low Poly Racing - Making Of - Episode 1:
https://youtu.be/ODVV3eUE5zM

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoWS_G-9Ntw

Check out Low Poly Racing - Making Of - Episode 3:

snippet.title: Blender 2.82 - Rigify to Unity Tutorial - How to Export a Rigify Character and Import it into Unity
snippet.description:
In this tutorial I will go through how I install an addon to Blender 2.82 to export a Rigify character and import it in Unity. I go through installing the addon, preparing the rig for Unity, parenting the character to the rig, exporting to Unity. I also describe the differences between Generic vs Humanoid rig settings in Unity with pros and cons (such as bone stretch / squash, retargeting, IK, performance). Then we'll set the rig up as a Humanoid in Unity and apply a simple walk cycle. Finally, a quick conversion to Generic rig typ and changing the walk animation to use root motion to propel the character forward.

I hope this video can help you out getting your Rigify character in Blender 2.82 / 2.83 to work in Unity 2019 and 2020.

If you want to see how I modeled the characters in this video and how I animated the walk cycle, check out this video:
https://youtu.be/TZDnV4KshM8

https://github.com/AlexLemminG/Rigify-To-Unity

snippet.title: Basics of Universal Render Pipeline (URP) in Unity 2019.3
snippet.description:
How to use URP ? Why should you choose it ? Let's find out.

Let's learn how to use Universal Render Pipeline (URP) in Unity 2019.3
We will also learn how to convert your existing project from built in pipeline to Universal Render Pipeline.

👉Note  : In Unity 2019.3 the LWRP or Lightweight Render Pipeline is renamed to Universal Render pipeline (URP) along with lots of graphical and performance improvements.

👉Note  : This video is mainly for Unity 2019.3 or newer version because URP is not available in 2019.2 or previous versions.

snippet.title: What are Subscenes in Unity? (Massive Worlds!)
snippet.description:
✅ Get the Project files and Utilities at https://unitycodemonkey.com/video.php?v=91kJtsDLTyE
Let's check out Subscenes in Unity, what they are and how we can use them to make Massive Worlds!
Subscenes use Unity DOTS / ECS in order to be insanely performant with nearly instant loading.
When closed they represent their contents as Entities and when you need to modify something you can open the Subscene which will convert all objects into Game Objects that you can edit as usual.

If you have any questions post them in the comments and I'll do my best to answer them.

snippet.title: How To INTERACT with Game Objects using UNITY EVENTS Tutorial
snippet.description:
Interacting with GameObjects within your scenes is a core tenet to game development within the Unity Engine. I wanted to engineer a system that would show off Unity Events, while also being generic enough to slap on to any of your objects and wire up quickly.

Admittedly there are many ways to improve upon the basics I show in the video (as well as lots of error checking and handling!), but I wanted to demonstrate the concept in a concise and timely manner. 

I'm confident this can be a useful launching point, and I hope you'll find it useful!

snippet.title: Make Your FIRST COMPLETE Game in Unity | BEGINNERS
snippet.description:
EXPAND FOR TIMESTAMPS - I make a breakout clone game and the entire process in real-time from start to finish. Including prototyping core mechanic, transitioning between game states, loading levels, spawning objects, cleaning up, keeping score, handling menu screen transitions, and high scores. This video is for beginners that want to learn about Unity and how to take the step to move from a game mechanic prototype and turning it into a "re-playable" game with menus.

Project Download: https://www.dropbox.com/s/qpk15rgs192s3o4/Imphenzia-SimpleBreakoutClone.zip?dl=0

In this video we will learn how to implement Unity's machine learning toolkit ML Agents into Unity's own Kart Racing Game project. We'll use reinforcement learning to train our AI agent to travel around the track autonomously by seeing with raycasts and steering to avoid obstacles.

snippet.title: 02/10 Rm 2 Talk 1 : Quickly Generate Game Character Behaviors & Animations using AI & ML
snippet.description:
You've seen artificial intelligence and machine learning in the news lately -- but what does it mean for game developers? AI and ML offer new mechanisms for generating animations and behaviors for game characters. In this talk, we will walk through the Unity Behavior Planner, Unity ML-Agents Toolkit and Unity Inference Engine, three tools that leverage state-of-the-art algorithms in AI to help you hit the ground running on your next game. We will showcase these tools with real examples. No need to be an expert in AI -- this talk is for anyone interested in harnessing new tools to help you do more, faster.

Jeffrey Shih (Unity Technologies)

snippet.title: How to Code a Simple State Machine (Unity Tutorial)
snippet.description:
🔥 Save 50% on ALL assets from Synty Studios with code SYNTY2021 (offer ends 9/11/21)
https://assetstore.unity.com/publisher-sale?aid=1100l3e8M

In this video, I'm going to teach you how to code a simple State Machine in Unity.

#Unity3d #UnityTutorial, #GameDevelopment

Have you ever written a method with two paths of execution? It probably had an if statement based on a member variable, right? But then your requirements changed, and you added another condition to handle a new state. And I bet they change again, over and over, until your code became a mess of hard-to-read flow logic and conditional statements.

If that's you, then you should learn about State Machines. State Machines are an implementation of the State Pattern, a behavioral design pattern that enables an object to control its internal behavior at runtime. In this Unity tutorial, I'll walk you through the implementation of a simple State Machine that handles the logic of a turn-based battle system.

📦 Download the Project: https://www.patreon.com/posts/32870529

snippet.title: Let's Build A Video Game With Unity and TensorFlow
snippet.description:
In this session, we’ll build a little smartphone game, train a bot to play it using reinforcement learning, Python, and TensorFlow, and deploy it to a smartphone.

In 30minutes. We’ll show you how easy it is to add ML-powered intelligence to video games or simulations, and how inference on smartphones is easier than it’s ever been: modern, powerful tools like Unity’s ML-Agents, Python, and TensorFlow make the complex easy. And it’s a lot of fun.

First, we’ll spend 10 minutes of the session:

* showcasing the absolute basics game engines

* creating an arcade game, live on stage

* adding some art, to make the game look pretty!

Second, we’ll spend 10 minutes of the session:

* implementing an agent, using Python and TensorFlow, that is rewarded for playing the game

* training the agent to play

* giving the agent some character

Finally, we’ll spend the last 10 minutes of the session:

* preparing our trained model for deployment onto a smartphone

* building the game and optimizing both the gameplay and ML-components for a smartphone

* showing the audience the game, running live on a phone!

This is an engaging, fast-paced, and surprisingly in-depth exploration of how powerful modern game engines can be used for quick, relatively easy, but incredibly powerful state of the art machine learning and training, and how powerful inference on-device is, for mobile AI.

You don’t need to be a game developer to see the benefits. Join us for 30minutes of rapid live coding, and engaging banter while we show what’s really possible with Python, TensorFlow for ML, game engines/simulations, and mobile devices!

In this session, we'll build a little smartphone game, train a bot to play it using reinforcement learning with Python and TensorFlow, and deploy it to a smartphone. In 30 minutes we'll show you how easy it is to add machine learning (ML)-powered intelligence to video games and simulations, and how useful it can be to visualize ML problems. It'll be fun, and you'll learn the fundamentals of ML.

EVENT:

North Bay Python 2019

SPEAKER:

Paris Buttfield-Addison

PUBLICATION PERMISSIONS:

Original video was published with the Creative Commons Attribution license (reuse allowed)

ATTRIBUTION CREDITS:

Original video source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8fLyMPPixdU

snippet.title: Unity Symmetry and Animation Curves
snippet.description: You can use simple symmetry and animation curves to get make cool enemies in a space invaders clone. I use Animation Curves that cycle through different body part rotations for enemy animations. The benefits of Animation Curves are that you can draw neat shapes that act as easing effects without having to use algorithms to calculate the easing effects. You can combine all sorts of bouncing, easing, and shaking effects for both rotations and movement.

snippet.title: Overview of Havok Physics in Unity - Unite Copenhagen
snippet.description:
This session gives an overview of the physics systems and workflows powering our Data-Oriented Technology Stack (DOTS). Viewers will gain insight into design considerations underlying Unity Physics, how its use cases differ from those of Havok Physics, and how both offerings express concepts familiar to users of our classic GameObject-based physics. This session covers content authoring workflows for DOTS physics, as well as the basics of the DOTS physics architecture and game code layer in order to help you achieve the best performance in your DOTS-based projects.

Speaker: Steve Ewart - Havok

Learn more about Havok Physics:  https://on.unity.com/2oaNyUg

snippet.title: Introduction to Unity.Mathematics - Unite Copenhagen
snippet.description:
This talk demonstrates how to solve common game-related math problems with Unity.Mathematics, such as building 4x4 matrices, manipulating rotations, and migrating existing code that uses Vector3f to Unity.Mathematics types like float3. The session also covers the basics of how Unity.Mathematics fits into DOTS and explores the differences between this system and the math operations currently implemented in Unity.

Speaker: Dale Kim – Unity

snippet.title: Keyboard and Joystick Controls in Unity 2019! (New Input System Tutorial)
snippet.description:
The new Input System in Unity allows us to quickly set up input for our player. In this video, we will learn how to adapt a twin-stick shooter character from using the current built-in input management system to the new input system using the new PlayerInput system. We'll look at how to implement moving and shooting controls for both keyboard and joystick.

Download the project here: https://ole.unity.com/keyboardmouse

Learn more about Input System here: https://on.unity.com/2ow2o8d

Whereas Unity’s current system is closed off and only internally has data about device discoveries and events that happen, the new system sends all data up to C# for processing to happen there.

This means that the bulk of the input system has moved into user land and out of the native runtime. This makes it possible to independently evolve the system as well as for users to entirely change the system if desired.

Aside from this fundamental architectural difference, we’ve tried to solve a wide range of issues that users have with the functionality of Unity’s current system as well as build a system that is able to cope with the challenges of input as it looks like today. Unity’s current system dates back to when keyboard, mouse, and gamepad were the only means of input for Unity games. On a general level, that means having a system capable of dealing with any kind of input -- and output, too (for haptics, for example).

snippet.title: Overview of Unity Simulation - Unite Copenhagen
snippet.description:
Unity Simulation can accelerate the training of your autonomous system by running at scale on the cloud to break the limitations of small onboard computing power. You can rapidly develop and test new features by spinning off millions of headless instances in Unity. In this video, you will learn how to set up the Unity Editor and run multiple Unity instances on Google GCP. 

Speakers:
Kevin Saito – Unity
Vladimir Oster – Unity

Learn more about Unity Simulation: https://on.unity.com/2nJQRkV

snippet.title: Converting your game to DOTS - Unite Copenhagen
snippet.description:
In this video, learn about what's involved in migrating existing game code to the new Data-Oriented Technology Stack (DOTS), which comprises the C# Job System, the Entity Component System (ECS), and the Burst Compiler. You'll also gain an understanding of the performance benefits you can expect from these systems. Finally, you'll learn when it makes sense to use them, and when to stick with the regular components you've used in the past.

Speaker: Mike Geig – Unity

Learn more about DOTS: https://on.unity.com/2mPaVBV

Slides available here: https://www.slideshare.net/unity3d/converting-your-game-to-dots-unite-copenhagen-2019

We'll discuss the fundamentals of testing, why we do it, how to get started, the anatomy of a basic unit test, how to write more complex tests, substitutes/mocks (with nsubstitute), red green refactoring, interfaces, extracting code to be testable, and a whole lot more.

snippet.title: Timeline Signals in Unity 2019!
snippet.description:
Download the project here: https://ole.unity.com/timeline_signals_demo

We’ve built Signals to establish a communication channel between Timeline and outside systems. But what does that mean? Why did we decide on this approach?

Let’s say that you are using Timeline to create a cutscene. When the cutscene ends, you want a new scene to be loaded and you want to enable a physics system. There are a couple of ways to implement this scenario:

When your cutscene ends, use custom scripts to make your Timeline instance interact directly with a scene manager and your physics system.
When your cutscene ends, create markers and signals to send a ‘’Cutscene finished’’ signal and have interested systems react to the signal.
The Timeline team went with the second approach because it keeps the emitter independent from the receiver. Keeping them independent adds a lot of flexibility, power, and reusability. To understand this more, let’s see how the different pieces work together.

snippet.title: Customize the Unity Editor with UIElements!
snippet.description:
UIElements is a new retained mode UI framework for Unity, available now as a public API for Unity 2019.1. In its current form, it’s a tool that makes it easier for you to extend the Unity Editor. In-game support and visual authoring will come in future releases.

➡️Learn more about UI Elements, and Download the Example Project here: 
https://ole.unity.com/uielementsdemo

Check out the blog post here:
https://ole.unity.com/UIElements

Traditionally, building custom Editor windows and inspectors in Unity meant using IMGUI, an immediate mode API. IMGUI makes it easy to start building user interfaces but fails to scale when you’re building more complex applications. It’s also difficult for the system to optimize rendering because the user can drastically change the structure of the UI at any time within the current frame. Lastly, all UI is declared in C# which means that any future tool for authoring UI visually would need to generate C# code, which is a complicated proposition.

In UIElements, as a retained mode API, the idea is that you build your UI hierarchy of objects and let the system render it for you. This way, the system can optimize what it draws, and when it draws, leading to better overall performance. This paradigm also lets you decouple your hierarchy and styling from functionality, which results in a better separation of concerns and more approachable UI authoring for both artists and programmers.unity

snippet.title: Unity New Input System - Update
snippet.description:
With the new update of the new input system of Unity 2019, major changes have been made to the syntax of the input system package. This lesson will teach you how to use this input system with the new updates. You will then be able to watch the rest of the lessons in or first-person tutorial series and adapt them to work with the latest version of the input system. 

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
Documentation: https://docs.unity3d.com/Packages/com.unity.inputsystem@0.2/manual/index.html
Post: http://www.infogamerhub.com/new-input-system-update/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

To get started you will need to create a new Unity project or open a project you want to use the input system in. Once the project is open you will need to import three input system. This is done by going up to the window dropdown menu and selecting package manager. You will then need to select the advanced dropdown menu and select show preview packages. we're will then scroll down and select Input System. You will then need to click the Import button. 

The next thing we will do is create a new input action asset. We can then open with full and create our different action maps and input actions. After this you will need to save the asset and generate a new C# class.  Next, you need to create your C# scripts to read in the different inputs.

snippet.title: Locking and Hiding Mouse Cursor in Unity
snippet.description:
For this tutorial, I will teach you how to make a simple cursor lock script that will lock your mouse cursor in the center of your screen and hide your cursor from view. This will help you look controls for your first person controller. Cursor locks are good for games such as FPS and car racing games but not so good for MMORPG and RTS. The number one reason for having a cursor lock script is so that you don't click outside your game selecting a different application.

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
For Code: http://www.infogamerhub.com/lock-cursor/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

To create the cursor lock feature we will start by creating a new input action file for all our general inputs. We will then add a keybinding for the escape key. Once you have this all set up we will then create a new script to read in the input. In this script, we need to register to our new input actions. When the player presses the escape key we want to toggle on and off the lock state of the mouse cursor and the visibility. We can also toggle on and off a menu panel for pausing the game.

snippet.title: Unity New Input System - Updating to Version 0.2.10
snippet.description:
Now that Unity has released their Unity 2019, there is a more up to date version of the input system. The new version of the input system has a number of changes that will throw errors in our first person controller project if we decide to update. In this video, we will update the input system and we will then fix the errors and should you how to make our first-person controllers work with the new input system. We will also be updating the downloads we have created of our first-person controllers.

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
Documentation: https://docs.unity3d.com/Packages/com.unity.inputsystem@0.2/manual/index.html
Post: http://www.infogamerhub.com/unity-new-input-system-updating/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

To get started you will first need to open your project with the latest version of Unity. You will then need to open the Package Manager window after which you can update the input system package. The next thing you will need to do is to reimport all your assets. Once your assets have been reimported you will need to regenerate the scripts created by you input action files. You can do this by deleting the old file and then use the input action file to generate a new one.

After this, we will fix the errors in our scripts. Once you have fixed all the compiler errors you will need to rearrange so our your functions. You should have new callback functions for each of the actions in your input action files. You will need to cut all the code from your old callback functions and paste them into the new callback functions respectively. After you have done this for both the basic first-person controller and the classic first-person controller you can save your scripts and test your project.

snippet.title: Using Cinemachine and Timeline Demonstration
snippet.description:
Sorry for the distorted mic. Not sure why its that way. I had my levels down a lot...
Anyhow. Here is the vague printed instructions I made before recording this video for my students:    Let me know if you have any questions.

1. Open Package manager and make sure timeline, Cinemachine and Post Processing packages are installed in your project.

2. Go to asset store and search "Goblin" and sort to free - then download and import the free lowpoly Goblin

3. Make a Terrain so he has an environment to run around in. a. set X and Z to -200 , then use raise terrain with brush to paint edges

4. Select GOBLIN in heirarchy hit F to focus on him, Move game view to see both Then hit play to watch animation

5. Stop playback.    Select main camera and add timeline - Create then save playable

6.  Delete animation track

7. Add Cinemachine track, link main cam, (this will make the brain)

8. Next make 2 Cinemachine Shot clips. in each one create a new CM vcam , Make Both cams look at Goblin

9.  Reset both Vcams and position them for movement

10.  then in the main camera timeline blend clips together almost all the way.  Hit play

11. Then  lets change the animation to a walk to show that it stays on him. 

12.  This is a legacy animation meaning it cant take advantage of the mecanim and rootmotion system so we are going to hack a workaround to make him move.

13. Make a new empty game object and name it MOVER, then drag it inside of goblin and reset it to make it exactly where he is. THen drag it back out and the Goblin into it.

14. Select MOVER and create a timeline and simple move animation for it in the timeline with auto keyframing.
DONE!

snippet.title: Unity New Input System Tutorial - Making a First-Person Controller - Crouching
snippet.description:
Welcome to this Unity tutorial on how to create a first-person controller using the new Input System of Unity. In this tutorial, I will teach you how to create a crouch mechanic for our classic first-person controller. After this lesson, we will have a complete classic first-person controller.

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
For Code: http://www.infogamerhub.com/first-person-controller-crouching/
Free Download: http://www.infogamerhub.com/classic-first-person-controller/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

The first thing that we need to do in this tutorial is to add another input action to our input action file. The key binding that we will set for this input action is the left ctrl key. You will then need to click the save asset button to update your input action file. Once we have added this input action we need to open our first-person controller script.

In this C# script, we will first need to add some variables. The two variable we need to add is both bool variables. After this, we will need to register our script to our new input action. You will then need to create the callback function for this action event. In this call back function, we will first check to see if our player is being crouch blocked. If we are we will then return if not we will continue. We will then be toggling the crouch position of the player. After this, we will then need to create a new function for our update function. In this function, we will check to see if there are any object right above our player while crouched. If there are object above the player then we want to set the isCrouchBlocked variable to true so that our player can't stand while blocked. We can then save this script an go back to Unity.

Once back in Unity, we can play our game and test our first-person controller. If you followed along with this tutorial you should be able to change the standing position of our player when the user clicks the left ctrl key. You should also be able to walk underneath an object or a tunnel and it will prevent your player from standing back up.

snippet.title: Unity New Input System Tutorial - Making a First-Person Controller - More Jump
snippet.description:
For this lesson, we will be updating the jump mechanic for our classic First-Person Controller. This tutorial will help you learn how to use the New Input System in Unity. We will improve our jump mechanic by making it so that the player will continue traveling in the same direction they are traveling while they are in the air.

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
For Code: http://www.infogamerhub.com/first-person-more-jump/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

The first thing we will need to do is open up our First person controller script. In this script, we will need to add two new variables for the movement speed of the player while they are in the air. We will then go down to the player movement function. In this function, we will need to add an if statement checking to see if the character controller is grounded. We will add this if statement around where we are adding the player's WASD input to the movement variable. After this, we can copy this if statement and paste it below. We will then change the second if statement to an else statement. We will need to change the multiplier from walk speed and strafing speed to the new variable we created. Next, we will scroll down to the other if statement where we check to see if the character controller is grounded. Right inside this if statement we will add a line of code where we will lerp the jump vector to zero. This will make it so our player will somewhat slide to a stop instead of stopping immediately. The last thing that we need to do is set the jump vector variable equal to the movement variable right inside where we are checking to see if isJumping is greater than zero. After this, we can save this script and go back to Unity.

Back in Unity we only need to set the two new variables we created in the inspector. We can then test our project. If you followed along with the video, you should have a better working jump mechanic for your classic first person controller.

snippet.title: Unity New Input System Tutorial - Making a First-Person Controller - Jump Mechanic
snippet.description:
In this lesson, on how to use the new input system in Unity to create a first person controller I will teach you how to program and create a basic jump mechanic. Jump mechanics like this can be found in almost every first-person shooter such as Halo, Call of Duty, and CS GO. 

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
Download Basic FP Controller: http://www.infogamerhub.com/basic-first-person-controller/
For Code: http://www.infogamerhub.com/first-person-jump/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

The first thing we will do in this video is to fix some stuff from the first three videos. These fixes are huge but they are important. Once we fix the code we will need to set up our input actions. We will need to set a keybinding for the spacebar. 

We will then go to our first-person controller and add some new variables. We will then need to register this script to the new action event. We will create the callback function in which we will set the is jumping variable to the input value. We can then add some code to our player movement function which will add a jump force to the movement variable when the play presses the spacebar. After this, we can save this script and we can go back to Unity.

Once back inside Unity we can we need to set our new variable. If you follow the video tutorial you should now have a working jump mechanic for your first-person controller.

snippet.title: Unity New Input System Tutorial - Making a First-Person Controller - Vertical Look
snippet.description:
For this tutorial on how to use the new input system in Unity, I will teach you how to make the vertical look mechanic that we complete our first-person controller. There are only the three features of this video and the previous two video that are required to create this basic first person controller. From here we will be able to expand on our first person controller and add additional features.

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/TuhJgge
For Code:http://www.infogamerhub.com/firstperson-verticallook/
Download Unity Package: http://www.infogamerhub.com/basic-first-person-controller/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

We will begin by going to our input action window. In here we will add an action for the delta y movement of our mouse. This will set up the new input system so that we can use this input to control the rotation of the camera game object. You will then need to save this action. We will then go into our FP Controller script.

Inside this C# script, we need to create some new variables. The first one will be a float for setting the speed of our vertical sensitivity. We then need a transform variable to hold the transform of the camera game object.  We then need three more floats. The first will be for the min camera angle then one for the max camera angle and finally the current camera angle. We will then need to register a new call back function to the y movement action. We then need to create this new callback function. Inside this function, we first need to read in the movement of the mouse in the y-direction and add it to our current angle variable. We will then clamp this variable and finally, we will apply this angle to the x rotation of our camera game object. We will then save this C# script and go back to Unity.

Inside Unity, all we have to do is set the new variable of our first person controller script in the inspector. Once we have done this we can then test our project. If you followed along with this tutorial you should now have a working first person controller.

snippet.title: Unity New Input System Tutorial - Making a First-Person Controller - Horizontal Look
snippet.description:
This is the second lesson for our tutorial series on how to make a first-person controller with the new input system in Unity. For this lesson, I will teach you how to program the horizontal look rotation of the first person controller. This horizontal look of our player will work well with the basic movement of our first-person controller. This will make it so that the movement of the player is based in the local space of the player. Following along with this lesson we give you a good example of our to use the new input system in Unity. 

Discord: https://discord.gg/hGJ4CRE
Website: https://infogamerhub.com
Become a Member: https://www.infogamerhub.com/product/basic-membership/

SUBSCRIBE for regular Video Game making videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCyoayn_uVt2I55ZCUuBVRcQ?sub_confirmation=1

The first thing we will do in this lesson is open the Input Actions window which if you do not already have it open then you can open it by double-clicking on the input action file we create in the last video. We then need to add a  new action to our FPContoller action map. We can then call this action MouseX and we will set the binding to delta/x [Mouse]. We then need to click on Save Assets in the Input Action window so that it can update the Input Control script Unity automatically created in the last lesson.

Now we will open up our first-person controller script. In this C# script, the first thing we need to do is add in a new variable. This variable will be a float and you can call it Horizontal Rotation Speed. Next, we need to register this script to the new input action events in the On Enable function. We then need to unregister in the On Disable function. We then need to create the callback function we want to be registered to the action event. I have called our function RotationAxisY. Inside this function, we are setting a local float variable to the float parameter being passed in. We then need to rotate the transform of this object in the y-axis by this input value. After this, we can then save our scripts and go back to Unity.

Inside Unity, we just need to seed the rotation speed variable. If you followed along with the video then you should have a working horizontal rotation in addition to the basic movement controls we created in the last video.

snippet.title: Unity Input System | How to Support Multiple Controllers
snippet.description:
🌎 Save up to 95% during the Level Design Mega Bundle Sale! Offer ends on May 31 https://assetstore.unity.com/mega-bundles/chart-your-course?aid=1100l3e8M

In this Unity tutorial you'll learn how to use Unity's new input system to enable multiple controller support in your game.

#unity3d #unitytips #gamedevelopment

The old Unity input API has been vastly improved by the new input system, which will be available in Unity 2019. The new input system API features input actions, a class that encapsulates controller input. With input actions, you can now bind arbitrary controls to your input logic, rather than polling input devices directly.

Be sure to follow along by downloading the Unity input system project (linked below). The project contains all of the code demonstrated in the video so you can learn hands on as you watch.

snippet.title: Unite Berlin 2018 - Become a Speed Demon Being Faster at Everything you Do in Unity
snippet.description:
In today's rapid world of game development, developers and creatives need to quickly adapt to changing requirements and deliver high-quality code and content in limited time. By using Unity, we already gain a lot of agility but we can always be better and faster. In this talk, we'll go over a myriad of tips, techniques, and tools we can use to speed ourselves up to the max! You will be amazed at how much is left on the table when it comes to speed and you will learn arcane techniques that others won't be able to distinguish from magic. Learn how to Become a Speed Demon in Unity!

Speakers:
Yilmaz Kiymaz - InnoGames GmbH

snippet.title: Underwater World Shaders - Unity CG/C# Tutorial [Part 0 - Introduction]
snippet.description:
A new tutorial series about creating an underwater world. We will be programming different types of shaders including:
- Surface Tesselation Vertex Displacement Shader
- Post Processing Image Effect Underwater Shader
- Surface Cutout Sinus Vertex Shader

Plus we will code our own particle system in a 3D noise flow field.

Combining all these things together, we will create a beautiful underwater scene, and along the way you'll learn all about shaders, and mathematics.

Created by Peter Olthof from Peer Play.

snippet.title: Unity at GDC - Job System & Entity Component System
snippet.description:
March 23, 11:00 am (San Francisco) - Learn about Unity 2018.1’s new C# job system for game code, as well as a new (experimental) Entity Component System implementation to go along with it. These new technologies make it possible to write highly performant code using C#, enabling you to make games with a higher frame rate and better battery life, while maintaining simplicity across both small and large projects. 

Speakers: 
Tim Johansson - Scripting Integration Developer at Unity

snippet.title: Unity at GDC - ECS for Small Things
snippet.description:
March 23, 4:00 pm (San Francisco) - Learn about Unity's new solution for creating smaller, faster, lighter experiences that will enable you to reach everything from entry-level devices to wearables. Our advanced compression techniques, combined with our Entity Component System architecture, leads to fast delivery, loading, and start-up times. Gain an understanding of what Unity's small solution is and what the various deployment options it makes possible. Learn about how it relates to the other Unity data-oriented design efforts and how we're thinking about small code going forward.

Speakers: 
Vlad Vukicevic, Senior Engineer, Emergent Technology at Unity

snippet.title: Unity at GDC - C# to Machine Code
snippet.description:
March 23, 2:30 pm (San Francisco) - Get an overview of the performance initiatives underway at Unity and share a deeper look at the technology developed to transform high-level C# code to efficient machine code. Dive into examples and look at traditional C++ engine code and compiler output to compare with our approach. Gain a better understanding of how Unity is solving the problem of optimizing game code and the technology that we’ve built to enable our solution.

Speaker:
Andreas Fredriksson, Principal Engineer at Unity

snippet.title: Unity at GDC - A Data Oriented Approach to Using Component Systems
snippet.description:
March 23, 1:00pm (San Francisco) - Mike Acton demonstrates best practices for component design to achieve a high degree of parallelism, minimum synchronization, and high performance. He focuses on data layout and uses common examples in games (e.g. spatial queries, logic updates, large hierarchical transformations – both static and dynamic). Discover new methods to examine your own component system transformations in order to redesign them using data-oriented principles, as well as concrete examples of data layout that you can use in your own systems.

Speaker:
Mike Acton, Principal Engineer at Unity

snippet.title: Using Cinemachine: State Driven Cameras
snippet.description:
Watch this video in context on the official Unity learn pages - http://unity3d.com/learn/tutorials/topics/animation/using-cinemachine-state-driven-cameras

The State Driven Camera feature of Cinemachine allows us to link our virtual cameras to animation states and further customise their behaviour in our scenes.

snippet.title: Using Cinemachine: Free Look
snippet.description:
Watch this video in context on the official Unity learn pages - http://unity3d.com/learn/tutorials/topics/animation/using-cinemachine-free-look

Cinemachine's Free Look component allows us to create an orbital camera system with input from the player and maintain control of our camera's composition at different stages of orbit.

More Info: https://unity3d.college

Pooling: https://unity3d.college/2017/05/25/unity3d-object-pooling-advanced/

snippet.title: Unite Austin 2017 - S.O.L.I.D. Unity
snippet.description:
S.O.L.I.D. is a collection of 5 programming principles that allow you to build larger applications, while keeping the code maintainable, flexible and, in general, with fewer bugs. The business world has enjoyed this in many languages for many years, but may seem impossible in Unity. Productive Edge explains what each of the five principles mean, along with examples, and most importantly, how to apply them in your own Unity coding. 

This talk also covers two great features as part of S.O.L.I.D. First, the use of DLL's instead of Scripts (optional), which allow you to add Unit Tests via MSTest or NUnit. Normally, this is impossible because of Unity's object duality (.NET/C++) throwing errors outside of Unity, but this talk teaches you how to get around that. Second, how to implement a Dependency Injection system, similar to Ninject, but designed for Unity, without requiring the designers to understand DI programming.

Dan Sagmiller (Senior VR Solutions Architect, Productive Edge)

snippet.title: Intro to Quaternion Rotations (in Unity)
snippet.description:
Written companion: http://HardlyDifficult.com/Tutorials/Quaternion

This tutorial introduces working with rotations, with a focus on Quaternions. Some math that goes into Quaternions is included; it may help to explain what these numbers represent, but it's not necessary to know when working with a game engine. By the end, you should feel comfortable using Quaternions in Unity.

Questions, comments, suggestions?  I want to make a useful reference, please leave comments here and I'll keep updating the written companion.

Thanks!

---------------------------------------------

snippet.title: How to create UI slider with text that shows percentage value in Unity | Simple Unity 2D tutorial
snippet.description:
#UnityTutorial #SimpleUnityGame #unityslidertext #unityslider
In this video I will show you how to create a slider with text field that shows the sliders value as percentage.

TO BLAST! - My New Fun Relaxing Puzzle Game Available On Google Play Store
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ZoGames.ToBlast

Consider purchasing my ULTIMATE UDEMY COURSE with great discount
https://www.udemy.com/how-to-make-games-with-unity-software/?couponCode=14-99-SALE-GOOD-LUCK

First create new UI Text game object. Position it in the right middle holding Alt+Shift keys. Change its text field. Modify its font size. Set overflow. Change its color. I change Canvas UI Scale Mode to Scale with Screen size so UI objects proportions will be the same regardless the screen size.
Next right click on the Canvas and create new UI slider. I scale it a bit. And chenge text alignment to look better. Our percentage text needs a C# script. Let's take a look at it. Here we use UnityEngine.UI library to have an access to UI elements. Also here is a reference to percentage text component. And finally we have a text Update method that will take a value from the slider multiplied by 100, rounded to Int and sets all of this to our percentage text component.
Add this C# script to our text game object. Then select slider object and proceed to its OnValueChanged section. Click plus button and drag and drop our text into object slot. Then click dropdown menu, proceed to ShowValueScript and choose textUpdate field under Dynamic float sign.
That's it. Hit play and see how it works.

You can support me through www.patreon.com/alexanderzotov
or here https://www.paypal.me/AZotov
Thank you)

snippet.title: Develop and Publish Flappy Bird in 3 Hours With Unity3D
snippet.description:
⭐ Kite is a free AI-powered coding assistant that will help you code faster and smarter. The Kite plugin integrates with all the top editors and IDEs to give you smart completions and documentation while you’re typing. I've been using Kite for 6 months and I love it! https://www.kite.com/get-kite/?utm_medium=referral&utm_source=youtube&utm_campaign=renaissancecoders&utm_content=description-only 


You can download it from the Play Store https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.rc.TappyBird

What should we clone next?

In this comprehensive tutorial, you will learn what it takes to build Flappy Bird from scratch. You will be walked through the entire development process in Unity3D, and be introduced to resources like Gimp, Bfxr, and flaticon.com. You will learn about art creation, UI placement for multiple screen resolutions, 2D physics, triggers, layers, parallaxing, object pooling, audio, and other miscellaneous topics.

Intro Music https://soundcloud.com/gramatik/10-gramatik-muy-tranquilo

Built with Unity3D https://unity3d.com/

Art Tool Used: https://www.gimp.org/

Art Resources Used: http://www.flaticon.com/

Audio Tool Used: http://www.bfxr.net/ 

Code Editor Used: https://code.visualstudio.com/

Learn more about:
User Interfaces: https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/UISystem.html
Rigidbody2D: https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/class-Rigidbody2D.html
Layers: https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/Layers.html
Tags: https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/Tags.html
Pooling: https://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/MobileOptimizationPracticalScriptingOptimizations.html
Parallax: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallax

Project Setup: 1:19
Art Development: 2:49
UI Design: 18:18
Physics: 33:57
Tags: 41:51
Layers: 44:40
C# Scripting: 50:04
Tap Controller: 50:26
Game Manager: 1:00:51
Button Events: 1:08:17
Count down Text: 1:11:02
Events and Delegates: 1:15:56
High score Text: 1:29:21
Parallaxing and Object Pooling: 1:31:25
Audio Effects: 2:29:30
Attribution: 2:41:27
Publishing: 2:42:45

Thanks for watching!


#unity3d #flappybird #gamedev

snippet.title: Unity Project - MiniMap - Guard on patrol detecting player
snippet.description:
Early footage of my current Unity Project that uses Sebastian Lagues "Field of View" demo as a foundation (thanks a ton!).

The blue enemy AI is walking a patrol route unless he detects the player. If it loses the player from its sights, it goes back on patrol.
--
Check out the "Field of View" tutorial this is based on: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLFt_AvWsXl0dohbtVgHDNmgZV_UY7xZv7

snippet.title: Adventure Game Unity Tutorial - Phase 1a of 6 - The Player
snippet.description:
For Download, Slides, Code and more - Watch this video in context on the Unity Learn pages here -
http://unity3d.com/learn/tutorials/projects/adventure-game-tutorial/player

Phase 1 teaches you how to build a click to move animated character using the EventSystem, NavMesh, Animator and Prefabs.

Originally shot at Unite LA 2016 Training day, the Adventure Game tutorial will teach you how to make a point and click adventure game. It is aimed at intermediate learners.

Trainers -
Adam Buckner (@theantranch)
James Bouckley

snippet.title: Introduction to Game Development (E01: variables and methods)
snippet.description:
Welcome to episode one of this introduction to game development in Unity with C#.
In this episode we look at the concepts of variables and methods.
Watch episode 02: https://youtu.be/XT_CtYN1OOU

If you'd like to support these videos, you can make a recurring monthly donation (cancellable at any time) through Patreon: http://bit.ly/sebPatreon

snippet.title: Field of view visualisation (E01)
snippet.description:
In this miniseries (2 episodes) we create a system to detect which targets are in our unit's field of view. This is useful for stealth games and the like.

Source code + starting file:
https://github.com/SebLague/Field-of-View

https://www.patreon.com/SebastianLague

snippet.title: Unity Tutorial: Radial Menu (Part 1) from Board to Bits
snippet.description:
Learn to make a dynamic radial menu using Unity's UI tools.

Beginner/Intermediate: Knowledge of basic scene setup and the Instantiate function recommended.

Part 2: https://youtu.be/HOOGIZu4nxo
Project sprites: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1AJ74NkKHw-X1dlUHRPdjBwZTg/view?usp=sharing

snippet.title: TANKS! Unity Tutorial - Phase 7 of 8 - Game Managers
snippet.description:
For Download, Slides, Code and more - Watch this video in context on the Unity Learn pages here -
http://unity3d.com/learn/tutorials/projects/tanks-tutorial/game-managers?playlist=20081

Phase 7 teaches you all about the architecture of the game, and we create two master scripts - the tank and game managers which handle creating the rounds and deciding the winner of the game. We also learn about coroutines and how they are used in scenarios like this.

Originally shot at Unite Boston 2015 Training day, the Tanks tutorial will teach you how to make a couch 2 player tank shooter game from scratch.

Help us caption & translate this video!

http://amara.org/v/V61L/
